Department of Mathematics and Physics Engineering, Faculty of Engineering at Mataria, Helwan University Cairo 11718 Egypt ⁎⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract Cobalt-chromium carbide-embedded carbon nanofibers (nanocomposite) were prepared via electrospinning of a solution containing cobalt acetate tetrahydrate (CoAc), chromium (II) acetate dimer monohydrate (CrAc), and polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP) followed by carbonization. Carbonization was achieved at a low temperature (850°C, Ar gas, 6h) as the nanocomposite contained metal carbide. The synthesized nanocomposite was analyzed using advanced analytical techniques. The catalytic activity of the nanocomposite in hydrogen liberation through the hydrolysis of aqueous ammonia borane (AB) solution was evaluated and compared to those of cobalt/carbon nanofibers (Co/CNFs) and cobalt nanoparticles (Co NPs). The synthesized nanocomposite showed the highest catalytic activity at 0.2475mol/min compared to Co/CNFs, 0.174molmin−1, and Co NPs, 0.09molmin−1. The synthesized nanocomposite also showed high stability; it was reused six times without makeup, reactivation, or regeneration. Kinetic studies showed that the rate of AB hydrolysis is dependent on the catalyst concentration and temperature; the value of turn over frequency (TOF) and the activation energy for the prepared nanocomposite were found to be 25.78 mol H 2 min − 1 ( mo l metal − 1 ) and ∼24.2kJmol−1, respectively. Keywords Electrospinning CoCrC/C composite Nanofibers Hydrogen generation Ammonia borane 1 Introduction The development of new, clean, eco-friendly, and sustainable energy is currently receiving more attention due to global energy-related environmental, population, and economic problems [1]. Although hydrogen provides a promising solution as a clean and renewable source for sustainable energy, efficient storage, transportation, and generation of hydrogen under ambient conditions present significant challenges for the development of a hydrogen-powered society [2]. Boron-containing compounds are promising solid chemical materials for hydrogen storage due to their light weight [3,4]. Among the various hydrogen storage materials, ammonia borane (NH3BH3, [AB]) is the best solid hydrogen source because it is nontoxic, has a hydrogen content of 19.6wt.%, higher than the U.S. Department of Energy's 2015 target weight of 5.5wt.%, low molecular weight (30.9gmol−1), and high stability [5–10]. To date, two methods have been demonstrated for releasing hydrogen from AB: (1) thermal decomposition in solid state, (2) alcoholysis or hydrolysis in aqueous solution. The latter has received considerable positive attention because of its favorable kinetics and mild reaction conditions [11–13]. However, to achieve hydrolysis an efficient and robust catalyst is required to overcome the strong bonds of AB [2]. Numerous types of catalytic nanoparticles (NPs) (i.e., Noble metal NPs, transition metal and metal oxide NPs, multicomponent metallic NPs) have been studied. Among them catalysts with precious metals have shown the greatest potential for promoting AB dehydrogenation at ambient temperatures [12] due to their high performance, durability and resistance to deactivation stability. Since they are scarce as well as expensive researchers are developing new and inexpensive catalysts. Because of their excellent electrical conductivity and stability transition metal carbides (TMCs) have recently received increased attention as the most promising replacements for Pt and its alloys [14]. TMCs, with their excellent mechanical and magnetic properties and high melting temperatures are currently used for wear-resistant coatings, cutting tools, and a wide range of applications [15,16]. While both titanium carbide and tungsten carbide have been used in catalytic chemical reactions, few studies have been conducted on the use of chromium carbides (CrCs) in catalytic chemical reactions. There are three forms of CrC (i.e., Cr3C2, Cr7C3, Cr23C6, CrCs) all with excellent electrical conductivity, high corrosion resistance, and good stability [17,18]. Given these characteristics and the high catalytic activity of titanium carbide and tungsten carbide, CrCs could demonstrate good catalytic activity in various chemical reactions. The added Co has multiple purposes. First, it will be used as a catalyst to enhance the formation of carbon from the utilized polymer. Second, it will promote the reaction between carbon and chromium. Third, it will increase the durability of Cr7C3. Lastly; Co is the most active transition metal used in AB dehydrogenation as well as it is an inexpensive. Furthermore, metal carbides have shown excellent catalytic capabilities in many chemical reactions. However, studies on the use of CrCs in catalytic reactions are rare. Moreover, there are no studies on the use of Cr7C3 for the release of hydrogen from AB. The catalytic properties of carbon nanofibers (CNFs), their high electrical conductivity and chemical inertness make them useful in applications such as biosensors, chemical energy storage, and as adsorbents for pollutants [19–26]. Co has also been used to enhance the formation of metal carbides because it facilitates the reaction of metal precursors with the carbon source and decreases the reaction temperature [27]. Co has shown unique catalytic activity in different catalytic reactions, especially in the generation of hydrogen through the hydrolysis of AB [28,29]. Composites have also been used to enhance chemical reactions. Therefore, the combination of CrC, Co, and CNFs could provide enhanced catalytic activity for hydrogen generation through AB hydrolysis. To the best of our knowledge, research has not been conducted on the use of a composite of CrC, Co, and a transition metal as a catalyst for hydrogen generation through the hydrolysis of AB. In this study we explored Co-CrC-C as a low-cost Pt-free catalyst for H2 gas release from AB. Recently, many studies have been shown that the catalytic activity of a nanostructure catalyst is higher than that of a regular catalyst. Nanostructures with high surface areas and porosity that can facilitate diffusion and their use leads to higher degrees of contact between reactant molecules [12,30]. NFs have high surface areas and low grain boundaries compared to NPs. The low grain boundary inhibits agglomeration phenomena during harsh catalytic reactions. Agglomeration of NPs is considered the most critical problem during the generation of hydrogen through the hydrolysis of AB [31]. Thus, researchers have made great efforts to prevent the agglomeration by supporting NPs on different structure matrices [32–34]. Our research group has synthesized different NF materials to enhance the generation of hydrogen through the hydrolysis of AB as well as to inhibit agglomeration [35–37]. In this study, a Co-Cr7C3-CNFs composite was prepared using the electrospinning (ES) technique. The synthesized composite exhibited excellent catalytic activity and a low activation energy in hydrogen generation through AB hydrolysis. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Nanocomposite preparation To fabricate the electrospun nanofibers composite, 2g of polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP, Sigma–Aldrich, average molecular weight ∼1300kgmol−1) was dissolved in a solution of acetic acid and ethanol (1:1; 8g each). The solution was stirred gently until transparent. Then, 1g of chromium (II) acetate dimer monohydrate (CrAc, Sigma–Aldrich) and 15wt.% cobalt acetate tetrahydrate (CoAc, Sigma–Aldrich) based on CrAc were then dissolved in 3mL of DI water and was added to the PVP solution. The solution was stirred gently at 70°C for 5h to produce a clear solution. The prepared sol–gel underwent magnetic stirring for another 24h at 25°C before the electrospinning (ES) process. The ES (lab scale with single-nozzle basic-level ES machine) of the prepared sol–gel was carried out by loading the sol–gel in a 10-mL plastic syringe. A rotating metal cylinder covered with a polyethylene sheet was used to collect the fiber composite. A high voltage (18kV) was applied between the needle and the cylinder to charge the solution through the needle; the tip-to-collector distance (TCD) was 15cm. The collected composite mats were kept in a vacuum dryer at 50°C for 24h to remove any solvent. The composite mats were calcined at 850°C for 6h with a heating rate of 2.3°Cmin−1. Co/C NFs were prepared using the same procedure. Commercially available Co NPs were used for comparison. 2.2 Nanocomposite characterization The surface morphology of composite nanofibers was studied using field-emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM, Hitachi S-7400, Japan). The crystalline structure of the composite nanofibers was examined using X-ray diffraction (XRD) (Rigaku Co., Japan) with Cu Kα radiation (λ =1.54056Å). The crystallinity of the composite nanofibers was investigated using selected-area electron diffraction patterns, and high-resolution images were obtained using a JEOL JEM-2200FS transmission electron microscopy (TEM) apparatus equipped with energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) capabilities operating at 200kV (JEOL Ltd., Japan). Inductively Coupled Plasma-Optical Emission Spectrometer (ICP-OES) (Thermo Scientific: iCAP 6000 Series, UK) was used for determination of the metal content in the prepared nanocomposite. 2.3 Hydrolytically release of H2 gas Hydrogen release from AB was achieved by using a water-filled gas buret system. A description of the process can be found elsewhere [38–40]. A specified amount of catalyst was added to an aqueous solution of AB (31.5mg) to generate a maximum of 3mol (67.2mL under standard conditions) of H2. After H2 evolution had stopped, the amount of water vapor was estimated and deducted from the total gas obtained. The amount of equivalent H2 generated per mole of AB was plotted against the reaction time. To determine the activation energy (E a ), the hydrogen release rate was measured at different temperatures. The recyclability of the composite was evaluated at 25°C with a molar ratio of (metal [Co+Cr]:AB)=0.0096. The same catalyst was used for all experiment cycles without regeneration, only an additional 31.5mg was added to the residual solution. 3 Results and discussion NFs, one-dimensional nanostructures, are excellent candidates for various applications due to their high axial ratios, manageability, good mechanical properties and unique physical properties [36]. Both organic and inorganic NFs can be prepared using various techniques (e.g., ES). In the case of inorganic NFs, the solution used for ES was consisted of a metallic precursor/polymer mixture in a proper solvent; they must be completely miscible to form the gel network. It is well known that metal acetates have been used as metallic precursors. They have a good ability to participate in polycondensation reactions to form electrospinnable sol–gels with proper polymers [41]. Electrospun nanofiber mats prepared from CrAc, CoAc, and PVP solutions have good morphologies, smooth and beads-free (Fig. 1A and B). Interestingly, owing to the polycondensation characteristics of the utilized metal and metal carbide precursors, the calcinations of the prepared electrospun nanofiber mats did not affect the nanofibrous morphology of the NFs. Fig. 1C and D shows the FESEM images of the obtained nanofibers after calcination, which indicate that good nanofibrous morphologies were obtained. Co has been used as an activator in the preparation of various metal carbides, enhancing the reaction between the metal and carbon. It is soluble in the formed metal carbide and stabilizes the formed crystal structure [42–44]. Fig. 2 shows the results of XRD analysis for the sintered NFs. Strong diffraction peaks corresponding to Cr7C3 (JCPDF; 36-1482, orthorhombic) and pure Co (JCPDF; 15-0806, face centered cubic) were detected. A peak observed at 2θ of 26.3° (d spacing of 3.37Å, JCPDF; 41-1487) indicated the presence of graphite-like carbon. The heating of CrAc, CoAc, and PVP under an inert gas leads to abnormal decomposition of polycondensate acetate anions, resulting in the formation of carbon monoxide and hydrogen as strong reducing gases. The formation of pure Co and Cr7C3 is attributed to the reduction of their salts by the formed gases as described in the literature [45,46,18]. Fig. 3 displays the results of TEM analyses; as shown in panel A (normal TEM image); dark crystalline particles are distributed along the selected NF. The high-resolution TEM image (panel B) indicates a crystalline structure (under the white arrow) attributed to Co and Cr7C3. The presence of crystalline carbon (under the green arrow) is hidden by the detected particles. The fringe distance was found to be 0.214nm which is different from the fringes lattice of Co and Cr7C3 [2,47]. In addition, it is difficult to distinguish between the Co and Cr7C3 (panel C) could be due to the high solubility of Co in Cr7C3 as well as its stability in an orthorhombic structure [42–44]. To test the previous hypothesis, affirm the XRD and TEM results and examine the composition of the formed nanocomposite, TEM line-EDX analysis was carried out (Fig. 4 ). It is clear that the NPs have good crystallinity (Fig. 4A). Line-EDX analysis was conducted at a randomly selected line (Fig. 4A). As shown in Fig. 4, Cr, Co, and C had similar distributions; this verifies the previous hypothesis about the complete solubility of Co in Cr7C3 and the formation of Co, Cr7C3, and C. According to the ICP-OES analyses, the nanocomposite contains 1.2wt.% and 4.1wt.% corresponding to Co and Cr, respectively. 3.1 Hydrogen generation studies Hydrogen was generated through the hydrolysis of AB in aqueous solution at 25±3°C to compare the catalytic activity of the prepared nanocomposite with those of Co/C NFs and Co NPs. Fig. 5 shows plots for number of equivalent H2 mol/number of AB mol versus time for the hydrolysis of aqueous AB solution in presence of the prepared nanocomposite, Co/C NFs, and Co NPs at 25±3°C. The molar ratio of active catalyst AB and reaction temperature were the same in the catalytic hydrolysis of AB using the three catalysts. Among the nanocatalysts tested, the prepared nanocomposite showed the highest catalytic activity. This was supported by the fact that hydrogen was released as soon as the nanocomposite made contact with the aqueous AB solution. The hydrogen yield obtained using the nanocomposite was very close to the expected yield from the reaction stoichiometry. It is clear in Fig. 5 that the hydrogen yield was directly proportional to the dehydrogenation time, indicating the AB hydrolysis rate follows pseudo-zero-order kinetics. It was noticed that the nanocomposite takes the less time for generation of 3mol of H2 gas compared to Co/C NFs and Co NPs and this may be attributed to the high catalytic activity of the nanocomposite. The highest catalytic activity of the nanocomposite can be attributed to the synergistic effect between Co and Cr7C3. It can also be attributed to the high adsorption capacity of carbon, which facilitates contact between the reactants and the catalyst surface. The nanofibrous morphology means a large surface area and an efficient site for hydrolysis. It should be noted that the catalytic activity of the Co/C NFs structure was higher than that of the Co NPs. This is because the high grain boundaries created on the NPs lead to high agglomeration to the bulk material. Fig. 6 displays the plots of the amount of equivalent hydrogen generated per mole of AB versus time during the catalytic dehydrogenation of 31.5mg of AB in aqueous solution at different catalyst concentrations at 25.0±3°C. It is well known that catalyst concentration is inversely proportional to reaction time. With increasing the catalyst concentration, the required time for releasing H2 gas from AB was decreased and the less time (10min) can be reached by using the catalyst:AB ratio of 0.0096 as shown in (Fig. 7A). The rate of hydrogen generation was determined from the linear portion of each plot in Fig. 7 and plotted against the concentration of the nanocomposite inset in Fig. 7. A straight line with a slope of 0.991 was obtained, indicating that the catalytic hydrolysis of AB is pseudo-first-order with respect to the concentration of the prepared nanocomposite. Catalytic hydrolysis of AB was conducted at different temperatures in the presence of the prepared nanocomposite (catalyst: AB=0.0095). Fig. 8 shows the plots of evolution of equivalent H2 per mol of AB versus time at temperatures ranging from 25°C to 50°C. The chemical reaction rate was increased as the temperature of the reaction increased, and thus higher amounts of hydrogen were generated with increasing temperature. The constant rate of reaction for the release of hydrogen was determined from the slope of the linear part of each plot of hydrogen evolution per mol of AB versus time obtained at the various temperatures (Fig. 7). The required E a for the hydrolysis of aqueous solution catalyzed by the prepared nanocomposite was determined from the slope of the Arrhenius plot inset Fig. 8, and was found to be 24.2kJmol−1. The catalytic activity of the prepared nanocomposite, calculated in terms of TOF was found to be 25.78 mol H 2 min − 1 ( mo l metal − 1 ) which is comparable to values reported in the literature for Co-based catalysts (Table 1 ). The reusability of the prepared nanocomposite was tested using successive experiments (Fig. 8) in the presence of 31.5mg of AB in aqueous solution. The nanocomposite was used six times without makeup, reactivation, or regeneration. Results of the reusability tests indicated that the catalytic activity of the nanocomposite in AB hydrolysis was decreased gradually, reaching approximately 61% at the sixth cycle. This decrease in the catalytic activity could be caused by the passivation of NFs surface due to the increase in boron products (e.g., metaborate) which might decrease the accessibility of active sites [48]. 4 Conclusions Cobalt-chromium-carbide nanoparticles embedded on carbon nanofibers (nanocomposite) were prepared through a one-step electrospinning of a solution containing cobalt acetate, chromium (II) acetate, and polyvinylpyrrolidone and then was carbonized at a low temperature (850°C) under Ar gas for 6h. The nanocomposite showed superb catalytic activity in the generation of hydrogen through the hydrolysis of AB compared to those of Co/C NFs and Co NPs at 25±3°C. The nanocomposite was reusable even after six cycles without makeup, reactivation, or regeneration with approximate activity of 61% at the sixth cycle. The activation energy (E a =24.2kJmol−1) for the prepared nanocomposite was low compared to those of catalysts reported in the literature. The main features of the prepared nanocomposite were high efficiency, cost effectiveness, and recyclability. The high catalytic activity may be attributed to the synergistic effects from all of the pristine components. coredata.dc:description: Cobalt-chromium carbide-embedded carbon nanofibers (nanocomposite) were prepared via electrospinning of a solution containing cobalt acetate tetrahydrate (CoAc), chromium (II) acetate dimer monohydrate (CrAc), and polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP) followed by carbonization. Carbonization was achieved at a low temperature (850°C, Ar gas, 6h) as the nanocomposite contained metal carbide. The synthesized nanocomposite was analyzed using advanced analytical techniques. The catalytic activity of the nanocomposite in hydrogen liberation through the hydrolysis of aqueous ammonia borane (AB) solution was evaluated and compared to those of cobalt/carbon nanofibers (Co/CNFs) and cobalt nanoparticles (Co NPs). The synthesized nanocomposite showed the highest catalytic activity at 0.2475mol/min compared to Co/CNFs, 0.174molmin−1, and Co NPs, 0.09molmin−1. The synthesized nanocomposite also showed high stability; it was reused six times without makeup, reactivation, or regeneration. Kinetic studies showed that the rate of AB hydrolysis is dependent on the catalyst concentration and temperature; the value of turn over frequency (TOF) and the activation energy for the prepared nanocomposite were found to be 25.78 mol H 2 min − 1 ( mo l metal − 1 ) and ∼24.2kJmol−1, respectively.
coredata.dc:title: Electrospun CoCr7C3-supported C nanofibers: Effective, durable, and chemically stable catalyst for H2 gas generation from ammonia borane
